elements.title: Wiley Griffon
elements.contents: ... that Wiley Griffon (pictured with streetcar) became the first streetcar operator in Eugene, Oregon, despite Black settlers being outlawed in the state?

elements.title: Martin Luther King Jr.'s speech "The Other America"
elements.contents: ... that Martin Luther King Jr.'s speech "The Other America" is thought to have been influenced by a post-Keynesian economist and a democratic socialist?

elements.title: Dorothy Homer
elements.contents: ... that Dorothy Homer declared her library was "dedicated to the principles of Democracy which cherish books while Dictatorships burn them"?

elements.title: a 2004 ballot measure to repeal Jim Crow laws in Alabama
elements.contents: ... that a 2004 ballot measure to repeal Jim Crow laws in Alabama failed after opponents claimed that taxes would spike?

elements.title: Ira L. Cooper
elements.contents: ... that Ira L. Cooper was the first African-American detective in St. Louis?

elements.title: a Chicago radio station
elements.contents: ... that an owner of a Chicago radio station attempted to destroy records of a documentary covering a race riot?

elements.title: John Vickers
elements.contents: ... that Quaker abolitionist John Vickers hid fugitive slaves in the kiln where he made pottery?

elements.title: The Artist & The Pervert
elements.contents: ... that both The Artist & The Pervert and Black Exhibition are described as significant works in the academic study of race and BDSM?

elements.title: more than 90 percent of Connecticut voters in 1876 agreed
elements.contents: ... that more than 90 percent of Connecticut voters in 1876 agreed to repeal the requirement of being white to vote?
